Award.AwardTitle: Second Annual Joint PI Meeting for the NSF BigData Research Program and the NSF Big Data Regional Innovation Hubs and Spokes Programs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The second annual joint Principal Investigators meeting for the Big Data program and the Big Data Hubs and Spokes program provides updates to progress on intellectual objectives and information sharing. The meeting will promote interaction between the participants in these programs, facilitate collaborations, expose students to the latest research, and situate the programs within the larger big data ecosystem.

The meeting will be a three-day meeting that includes one day dedicated to each program and a third day shared between the two. The agenda includes breakouts, panel discussions, lightning talks, and poster sessions to encourage intellectual engagement across the programs, thus setting conditions for new projects and multi-disciplinary activities. The meeting will produce a report that highlights outcomes for broader dissemination and sharing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The second annual joint PI meeting of the NSF BIGDATA Research Program and the NSF Big Data Hubs and Spokes programs was held on June 20-22, 2018, at the Westin Alexandria Hotel in Alexandria, VA.

The goals of the meeting were to promote interaction between the participants in the programs, to facilitate collaborations, to increase awareness of related funding opportunities, to facilitate interactions with industry partners, to provide exposure to students to the latest research in Big Data, and to help situate the two programs within the larger Big Data ecosystem.

June 20 was devoted to the NSF BIGDATA Research program; June 21 was a joint meeting day, and June 22 was devoted to the Hubs and Spokes programs. There were more than 200 attendees. ~160 people attended the BIGDATA Research sessions on June 20, ~180 people attended the joint sessions on June 21, and ~84 people attended the Hubs and Spokes sessions on June 22. There were 6 Government agencies represented, ~100 Universities represented, and over 130 projects shared by PIs in lightning talks and poster sessions. Twenty-five students and postdocs also attended the program. They benefited from being exposed to the range of work being done within and outside academia in the Big Data ecosystem.

There were a number of sessions over the three days, including invited talks, panel discussions, "lightning" presentations of projects (one minute, one slide), and poster sessions. Some details are presented below.

The keynote talk on June 20 was given by Professor Susan Davidson, of the University of Pennsylvania. Her talk was titled, "Data Citation: Giving Credit Where Credit is Due." Professor Davidson discussed the problem of generating citations for data in a database in an automated manner, depending on both the query (how the data was extracted) and the data itself (the content of the query result). She related this problem to two well-known problems in databases: query rewriting using views and provenance.

In the afternoon, Professor Etsuya Shibayama of the Japan Science and Technology Delegation and the University of Tokyo, presented some remarks titled, "An Overview of Big Data Research Programs in Japan and Collaborative Activities with the US." JST and NSF have started a series of symposia and workshops in Big Data and related areas, with the goal of promoting collaborative activities.

This was followed by a panel discussion about the NSF TRIPODS Program. Participants were Professor Katya Scheinberg of Lehigh University, Professor Helen Zhang of University of Arizona, and Professor Eli Upfal of Brown University. The session was moderated by Dr. Melissa Cragin of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and the Midwest Big Data Hub.

Throughout the day, PIs from the BIGDATA Research Program exhibited posters about their projects and presented their work in lightning talks.

On June 21, which was a joint day for all programs, the keynote talk was given by Professor Michael Franklin of the University of Chicago, titled, "Data Science: A New Discipline or Just Another Venn Diagram?" He discussed the emerging field of Data Science. He suggested that while treating Data Science as simply a combination of topics from existing fields (a "Venn Diagram") has practical advantages, the challenges raised by Data Science indicate that it should be pursued as a new discipline in its own right. He discussed the intellectual opportunities and research questions that could lie at the heart of this new discipline.

After this there were four parallel breakout sessions. The topics were, "Foundational Big Data Algorithms", "Big Data and Health/Medicine", "Big Data, Learning Analytics, and Theory", and "Large-scale Inference and Learning."

This was followed by two Birds-of-a-feather sessions, on "The Cloud", which discussed "NSF-funded research enhanced by the Cloud credits, usage of Cloud credits and experiences," and on "Data Sharing", which discussed "NSF-funded Open Storage Network, Sharing Datasets from Microsoft Research, and other collaboration opportunities."

The afternoon session featured an NSF panel discussion, followed by a "High-level Hubs Discussion," featuring the PIs of the NSF Big Data Hubs. The next session was a Government Agencies Panel, which included participants from USDOT, NIFA, NLM, DOE, and AFRL/RIT.

PIs from all research programs exhibited posters about their projects throughout the day.

On June 22, in the morning session there was a panel discussion in the morning featuring the Executive Directors of the four NSF Big Data Hubs, titled, "Hub Success Stories: Regional Uniqueness, Regional Success".

The afternoon session featured three breakout sessions. Topics were, "Using Big Data for Social Good", "Big Data and Smart Cities", and "Forming Interdisciplinary Partnerships."

The Spoke PIs also presented their projects in a lightning talks session.

Overall, the meeting was very successful, and feedback was overwhelmingly positive. Information about the meeting, as it took place, was also disseminated over social media.
